awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  The xAristotle Platform for Advanced X-ray Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project takes several forms.  The basic product enables new hands-on undergraduate instruction in advanced x-ray methods for use in development of electrical energy storage and catalysis systems. Next, upgraded versions of this product will open a new market for use of these x-ray methods in industrial quality control and expand the market for the same methods in specialized research in academia and national labs.  Likely applications include quality control for lithium-ion-battery components, research into catalysts and electrocatalysts in the clean energy sector, and rapid screening of engineered nanophases for many applications spanning from clean energy to consumer products.  

The proposed project addresses the core problem posed by the absence of entry-level capability for the advanced x-ray method known as x-ray absorption fine structure, or XAFS.  Here, by entry level, we mean suitable in cost and performance for use in undergraduate education in advanced instructional laboratories in chemistry, physics, chemical engineering and materials science, or similarly suitable for use in certain applications in industry and academia where very high access but relatively low technical capability is required.  We will build on existing prototype capabilities to develop miniaturized benchtop XAFS capability capable of attaching to an existing x-ray diffraction source.  Effort will include testing of different optical and detector components and work to decrease background scattering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements are widely used across the sciences to innovate materials and devices for next generation technology. The wide-ranging structural and chemical analysis capabilities of this advanced X-ray technique have enabled numerous breakthroughs in the development of batteries, catalysis, and other technologies. However, easy and rapid access to this technique remains challenging with instruments primarily only available at large scale synchrotron facilities. easyXAFS LLC has developed general purpose laboratory instruments that have increased "research grade" access to XAFS. As a result of this easy availability, laboratory-based instruments have pushed the boundaries of materials testing in general research laboratories.

Going one step further, this Phase I STTR focused on the development of a low cost introductory XAFS instrument to help XAFS attain the widespread use of other mature market X-ray techniques. Focusing on entry‑level capability, this new instrument (referred to as the xAristotle) was designed to be easy-to-use with rapid set-up and data collection. These capabilities make the xAristotle suitable for education, hands‑on proficiency training, and basic research testing. By fine‑tuning our choice of x-ray source, optical, and detector components, the miniaturized xAristotle setup was successfully used to probe next generation manganese-based battery materials. This solidifies the xAristotle's research capabilities for academic and industrial applications where basic performance is needed such as with quality control of lithium-ion batteries and catalysts.

In tandem with the creation of the xAristotle instrument, collaborators at the University of Washington developed an open access educational X-ray absorption resource workbook (https://github.com/XASResourceWorkbook) to introduce the XAFS technique to new users. The worksheets primarily rely on visual exercises with limited in-depth derivations to enable rapid proficiency training. These workbooks can be implemented in existing undergraduate courses to expose future scientists to XAS. By hosting publicly on GitHub, these resources are also out in the public for open access and for feedback; anybody can raise an issue or post questions that can be used to continually improve this informational material.

As a result of this Phase I STTR, the xAristotle is poised to be the first commercial introductory level XAFS instrument. The xAristotle has the potential to generate large-scale access to XAFS and solidify this technique as a standard analytical technique in academic and industrial research.
